imaging+ 0.2-beta documentation /In this notebook, we demonstrate the basics of how data is organized inside of a trial object.

ipython3
from IPython import display
none
[2]:
ipython3
import packerlabimaging as pkg

Warning: cellpose did not import
No module named 'cellpose'
cannot use anatomical mode, but otherwise suite2p will run normally
import packerlabimaging
        version: under...alpha...development

In this notebook, we demonstrate the basics of how data is organized inside of a trial object.¶

First, an already existing trial object is loaded:

none
[3]:
ipython3
# import trial object to use as example

trialobj = pkg.import_obj(pkl_path='/home/pshah/Documents/code/packerlabimaging/tests/2020-12-19_t-013.pkl')

|- Loaded (RL109 t-013) TwoPhotonImagingTrial.alloptical experimental trial object, last saved: Sat Jan 22 04:01:26 2022

The AnnData library is used to store data in an efficient, multi-functional format. This is stored under: trialobject.data .

The AnnData object is built around the raw Flu matrix of each trialobject . In keeping with AnnData conventions, the data structure is organized in n observations (obs) x m variables (var), where observations are suite2p ROIs and variables are imaging frame timepoints.

none
[4]:
ipython3
display.Image("/home/pshah/Documents/code/packerlabimaging/files/packerlabimaging-anndata-integration-01.jpg")
none
[4]:
none
[5]:
ipython3
trialobj.data  # this is the anndata object for this trial
none
[5]:

Annotated Data of n_obs (# ROIs) × n_vars (# Frames) = 640 × 16368
available attributes:
        .X (primary datamatrix, with .data_label):
                |-- Suite2p Raw (neuropil substracted)
        .obs (ROIs metadata) keys:
                |-- 'original_index', 'footprint', 'mrs', 'mrs0', 'compact', 'med', 'npix', 'radius', 'aspect_ratio', 'npix_norm', 'skew', 'std'
        .var (frames metadata) keys:
                |-- 'frame_clock', 'x_galvo_uncaging', 'slm2packio', 'markpoints2packio', 'packio2slm', 'packio2markpoints', 'pycontrol_rsync', 'voltage', 'photostim_frame', 'stim_start_frame'
        .obsm keys:
                |-- 'ypix', 'xpix'
        .layers keys:
                |-- 'dFF'

storage of Flu data¶

The raw data is stored in .X

Processed data is added to trialobj.data as a unique layers key.

shape:  (640, 16368)

The rest of the AnnData data object is built according to the dimensions of the original Flu data input.

observations (Suite2p ROIs metadata and associated processing info)¶

For instance, the metadata for each suite2p ROI stored in Suite2p’s stat.npy output is added to trialobject.data under obs and obsm (1D and >1-D observations annotations, respectively).

none

trialobj.data.obs

none
[10]:
ipython3
trialobj.data.obsm
none
[10]:

AxisArrays with keys: ypix, xpix

The .obsm includes the ypix and xpix outputs for each suite2p ROI which represent the pixel locations of the ROI mask.

none

print('ypix:', trialobj.data.obsm['ypix'][:5], '\n\nxpix: \t', trialobj.data.obsm['xpix'][:5])

variables (temporal synchronization of paq channels and imaging)¶

And the temporal synchronization data of the experiment collected in .paq output is added to the variables annotations under var. These variables are timed to the imaging frame clock timings. The total # of variables is the number of imaging frames in the original Flu data input.

none
[ ]:
ipython3
none

ipython3
import pandas as pd
pd.options.display.max_rows = 999
